Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.RegulatoryContext1: The United States Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) regulates jurisdictional waters of the United States (WOTUS) under the federal Clean Water Act (CWA), via CWA Section 404 and Section 401 permits. The Nevada Department of Environmental Protection (NDEP) regulates and permits various activities in aquatic resources determined to be Waters of the State (WOTS).
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Description1: An Aquatic Resources Screening Report is a technical memo that describes the lateral extent of aquatic features located within a project boundary and assesses the need for the proposed project to obtain permits from the USACE and NDEP.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Methods1: UES will conduct a desktop review of publicly available data sources and aerial imagery. UES will also conduct a site visit to document current field conditions of the project area identified by the Client. Field data to be collected includes georeferenced photographs, ordinary high water mark (OHWM) measurements, and general site descriptions.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.CPI1: Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.AandL2: Weather is conducive to field work
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.AandL3: Client comments will be editorial in nature
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Deliverables1: A draft screening report will be submitted for the client to review.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Deliverables2: One round of client comments will be incorporated into the draft report.
Aquatic Resources Screening with Fieldwo.Deliverables3: A final report will be submitted to the client for their records

NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Task1: NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.RegulatoryContext1: During the planned project activities, work will be done in watercourses, drainages, stormwater channels, and/or other features that are Waters of the State of Nevada (WOTS). WOTS are regulated by the Nevada Department of Environmental Protection (NDEP). NDEP requires a Working in Waters permit for any work done with “heavy equipment” in WOTS. A temporary Working in Waters (WIW) Permit is valid for 180 days from issuance. A project may obtain up to two temporary permits per project (which may be defined differently by NDEP than the client) before an individual permit (valid for up to five years) is necessary.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Description1: UES will coordinate on behalf of the client to obtain a temporary WIW permit from NDEP. This task includes field work, client coordination, submittal package, monitoring log, and agency coordination.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.CPI1: Project boundary in electronic format (.kml or .shp)
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.AandL2: Weather is conducive to field work
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.AandL3: Client comments will be editorial in nature
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Deliverables1: A draft screening report will be submitted for the client to review.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Deliverables2: One round of client comments will be incorporated into the draft report.
NDEP Temporary Working in Waters Permit.Deliverables3: A final report will be submitted to the client for their records
